content.description: Start just left of the ledge and climb up and left on good holds to a stance just below the slightly overhanging face directly left of the large roof. Angle up and left, using the corner or sticking to the face past three bolts to a jug at the lip. From here mantle up and walk/traverse right following large crack (5.3 but runout, bring a cam if you want) towards the stacked boulder. Mantle over this to 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.protection: 7 bolts to two bolt anchor w/chains
content.location: Located just left the small (usually wet) vegetated ledge, below a large roof.

content.description: Start at the base of a large left facing corner. And follow the crack system exiting left under the roof. I would say it's the hardest 5.6 I've ever climbed but that's what we've traditionally rated it. It's long pitch and eats a lot of gear.

The route starts from the ledge half way up the cliff to the right of ‘Proud Boys in a Blender’. The route starts just to the right of the stack of boulders halfway out the ledge. Follow holds off the ledge past two bolts up and slightly left to a large in-cut horizontal edge. Next head up and slightly right past three bolts to the base of the roof. It is possible to climb either side of the next section of the bolt line, left being easier while the right being more difficult. Once at the base of the left facing corner in the roof, head out and mantle the lip. Follow easy climbing to 2 quick clip anchors. 6 Bolts.
content.protection: 6 Bolts to a 2 bolt Anchor with clips
content.location: Starts on the midway ledge about 10ft right of the Waning Light anchors.

content.description: This route starts from the Eagle's Perch ledge and ascends closely along the right side of the sweeping arete. From the ledge, start just left of the Eagle Horns anchor and clip the first bolt. Then traverse left, staying low, past another bolt to the edge. Soar along the arete, staying as close to the edge as possible past a few more bolts. As the arete ends, step right and follow a blocky section to a small roof. Climb over the roof and land at the 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.protection: 8 Bolts to 2 Bolt Anchor with chains
content.location: Start on Eagle's Perch (top of Eagle Horns' first pitch)

content.description: Shoo-B-Doop, climbs straight up just left of the pine tree in the middle of the slab on the right end of Eagle Ledge. Climbing past the pine tree continue up straight through the dish (5.5) or avoid mantle by using easy holds to the right (5.4). Climb over the last short face from (R > L) for the cooler holds to two bolt anchor.
content.location: Far right end of Eagle Ledge. Easily locatable by the pine tree half way up the slab.

content.description: This varied climb starts up a slab below a large left facing corner. Begin just left of the large diagonal pine tree crack and climb the fun easy slab past two bolts to the base of the left facing corner. Work your way up the left facing corner (5.8) or head straight up the middle of the steep slab (5.10) to a stance at the large left facing corner below the main roof. Balance your way up into the corner and exit left around the roof on great holds with some nice exposure. Easy climbing leads to two bolt anchor (clips).
content.protection: 5 Bolts to 2 bolt anchor with hooks.
content.location: Located and the far right end of the cliff on the Town Slabs, about 25 ft to the left of Shoo-B-Doop.

content.description: Starting ~150ft right of Waning Light at the base of a clean section of slab ascend past two bolts (crux) to the small overlap (3rd bolt). Continue straight up more vertical terrain and just after the 5th bolt, step left over the left facing corner to another clean slab section. Best to avoid using the mossy left facing corner, continue climbing past four more bolts to two bolt anchor w/ chains.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2 bolt anchor w/ chains
content.location: Located at the left end of the Town Slab and about 150ft right of Waning Light

content.description: Starting on the corner 10 feet right of Eagle's Horn ascends the face to the small overhanging corner.  Head past the roof on good holds to gain the first small ledge. Ascend the inside corner to the overhanging face. Continue up and right to a mantle at the lip of the large ledge. After gaining the ledge step left and climb up the right side of the roof. Once over the roof cruise along using jugs to the anchor. Shares the last bolt and anchor of Eagle Horns.
content.protection: 7 Bolts to 2 Bolt anchors w/ Chains.
content.location: ~10ft left of Eagle Horns start just below a pointy roof.

content.description: Trad crack climb with brain teasers.  Can be grunty.   Starts in an open book with a bolt belowright of  the left ledge.There are variants as you go up.   Anchors at the top.   Var. that disappears, Do the  first crux and then go left along the edge to the corner, go to top.
content.location: Around the corner to the east from TS. Open book with a bolt leading up and left.

content.description: This route climbs the steep and overhanging ledges to the right of the Eagle Shits corner. Starting in the left facing corner, head up to a rest beneath the first roof. After the large detached flake head up and then out left on nicely exposed overhang to the large horn on the arete. Mantle up onto the horn for a rest and then repeat to gain the large ledge. From here head up and left out the small roof to gain a shallow left facing corner. Climb through this bouldery section and once on easy climb head right past a bolt to top out on the Eagle perch. Pitch two heads straight up from here climbing through several large roofs with exciting exposure and fantastic views.
content.location: About 50 ft to the right of the large left facing corner of Eagle Shits.

content.description: Eagle Ledge is the main and largest cliff in the Hollow, standing 160ft tall. Rock climbing has never been popular here but has been quietly taking place for over 50 years now. The main section of the cliff is comprised of sections with distinctly different characteristics. The first area to the left of the approach trail is mostly vertical with some slabs and small roofs. Where the approach trail meets the cliff are the two most impressive features, two massive left facing corners where the left wall is slaby and the right wall is steeply overhung. Beyond these two corners the wall tends to be more vertical and comprised of small aretes and roofs. Beyond that section the wall turns entirely slab and offers some outstanding beginner climbing for all to hone their skills and test their nerves. At the end of the main slab section the trail leads to the top of the cliff or continues (less traveled) to the PHAR End walls.
